19.48.text:
Our rivers and canals
provide something for everyone:

27.72.text:
or just relaxing into
a whole new, slow pace of life.

31.56.text: One of the most important contributions

33.56.text:
to your enjoyment
of this wonderful waterways world

36.28.text:
will be you and your crew's ability
to handle the boat

39.32.text:
and operate the locks
safely and without stress.

42.92.text:
This DVD aims to take the worry out of
steering and handling a narrowboat

49.64.text:
to enable you and your crew
to enjoy your time spent on the water.

54.68.text:
Crewing a boat is a team effort with
everyone mucking in and doing their bit.

59.36.text:
However, someone has to be in charge,
and that person needs to ensure

63.20.text:
that everyone knows
what they're expected to do.

66.04.text:
You'll need to decide which
of your party will be the skipper.

72.00.text:
make sure that you understand
how everything on your boat works

75.20.text:
and that you can carry out
all the necessary routine checks.

79.00.text:
Also, make sure you know
the location of the fire extinguishers

84.16.text:
and that everyone knows exactly
what to do if a fire should break out.

88.04.text: Although fires and explosions are rare,

90.36.text:
it's important that
you're aware of the risks.

93.12.text:
LPG bottled gas, used for cookers
and heaters, is heavier than air,

97.68.text:
and if there's a leak, it will build up
in the bottom of the boat

100.72.text: and could be ignited by a spark.

103.12.text:
Always keep ventilators open
and free from obstruction.

107.08.text:
If you smell gas,
immediately turn it off at the cylinder.

110.88.text:
If there's an incident,
switch off the gas,

113.60.text:
steer the boat to the bank
and secure it,

116.20.text:
get all the crew ashore
and call for help.

124.32.text:
Remember the water can be very deep
and, at times, extremely cold.

133.24.text:
Start the engine
and if you've used mooring pins,

136.00.text:
remove them by twisting
and pulling straight out

138.52.text: so as not to damage the bank.

141.00.text:
If you're in deep water,
untie the front rope and push off.

144.88.text:
Do the same with the back,
then motor away from the bank.

147.84.text:
Make sure you keep
the deck areas tidy.

150.16.text:
Loose items of gear
can be a trip hazard.

155.20.text:
If a rope trails in the water,
it can easily foul the propeller.

159.64.text:
If you're in shallow water
or moored close to other boats,

162.72.text:
it's a good idea
to push the back out first

165.20.text:
and use reverse gear
to get well clear of the bank

168.00.text:
before engaging forward gear
to motor away.

174.16.text:
When travelling, always keep within
the profile of the boat;

177.68.text: a steel narrowboat weighs several tons

180.04.text: and you don't want any limbs or heads

181.96.text:
between it and a hard place
or another boat.

185.24.text:
If you need to get from one end of
the boat to the other whilst under way,

189.04.text:
go through the boat
rather than walking along the side.

196.56.text:
When you need to stop your boat,
remember it doesn't have brakes

200.32.text:
and it's important to give yourself
plenty of time.

203.28.text: Ease off the throttle, move into neutral

205.88.text:
and then use short bursts
in reverse gear

208.32.text:
to slow the boat down
and come to rest.

211.08.text:
Your boat won't always stop
in a straight line,

213.72.text:
and may need a short burst of
forward gear to correct its position.

222.96.text:
Most canal boats
are steered using a tiller,

225.44.text:
which is quite simple
once you've had a little practice.

228.64.text:
Always stand in front of the tiller
so it can't knock you

231.52.text:
if the rudder hits something
under the water

233.76.text: and swings the tiller over unexpectedly.

236.36.text:
Likewise, keep crew members
clear of the tiller.

240.64.text:
Steering a 50- or 60-foot-long boat
down a narrow canal

244.60.text: might seem a little daunting at first

246.64.text:
but if you remember a few basic things,
you'll soon get the hang of it.

250.92.text:
Always think ahead and line the boat up
for bridges and locks well in advance.

255.80.text:
Don't go on the roof of the boat
while under way.

258.52.text:
Bridges and overhanging branches
can easily sweep you off.

262.56.text:
When steering, there are
two main principles to bear in mind.

266.12.text:
Firstly, the boat can only be steered
when the engine is in forward gear,

270.04.text:
which creates a flow of water
across the rudder.

275.80.text:
Secondly, a narrowboat
doesn't turn like a car,

278.96.text: with the back following the front.

280.72.text:
Instead the boat will pivot around
a point roughly halfway down its length.

285.28.text: The boat is steered by the rudder

287.04.text:
"pushing" the back in one direction
which, in turn,

290.40.text:
causes the front
to move in the opposite direction.

292.96.text:
So it's important to allow for the swing
of the back when manoeuvring the boat.

297.72.text:
The secret is to let the front go past
the point where you want to turn

301.28.text:
before pushing the tiller over
to take the boat around,

304.36.text:
otherwise you run the risk
of cutting the corner

306.80.text:
which can sometimes
take you into shallow water

309.36.text: and you may even run aground.

311.48.text:
On bends, keep towards the outside
where there is usually deeper water.

320.72.text:
If you do run aground, don't panic;
it's easy to sort out.

324.72.text:
Simply get your crew
onto the side of the boat

328.84.text:
then gently reverse away
from the obstruction.

332.04.text:
Trying to go forward
will just make matters worse.

335.32.text:
Selecting reverse gear will flush water
under the boat, floating it off.

341.72.text:
If you're in very shallow water,
you may have to use the pole

345.12.text:
to push the back out into deeper water
before reversing.

348.52.text:
Make sure you use the pole against a
solid object or the bed of the waterway,

353.00.text: not against another boat or as a lever.

356.80.text:
Give yourself enough room to straighten
up and steer away from the obstruction.

365.44.text:
If you want to turn the boat round,
look for a turning place,

368.80.text: which is called a winding hole

370.48.text:
and will be marked in the guidebook
by a curved arrow.

373.56.text:
Most winding holes have a rough V shape
cut into the bank opposite the towpath.

378.60.text:
To turn your boat,
put the front of the boat into the V,

381.56.text: then use your engine in forward gear

383.76.text:
or use a pole to push
the back of the boat round slowly.

389.92.text:
engage reverse to pull
the front of the boat off the bank

393.24.text: until you can steer away forward.

395.88.text:
Watch out for shallow water
at the towpath edge.

403.24.text:
The cardinal rule with all manoeuvres
on the water

406.12.text:
is to think it through first
and perform the manoeuvre slowly.

410.20.text:
Slow right down,
just short of where you want to moor,

413.16.text: with your boat parallel to the bank.

417.00.text:
Have a crew member ready at the front
and move forward slowly,

422.28.text:
Before the boat touches,
use reverse to stop the boat

425.68.text:
and let your crew member step off
with a mooring rope.

430.28.text:
it's all too easy to slip
between the boat and the bank.

434.44.text:
If there's a convenient ring or bollard,
use this to help steady the boat,

438.36.text:
but don't pull it tight
or you'll prevent the back coming in.

442.00.text:
With the tiller
pointing towards the bank,

444.12.text: use the engine to bring the back in,

446.44.text:
then use reverse gear
to bring the boat to a halt,

449.00.text:
allowing you or another crew member
to step off the back with a rope.

453.16.text:
Pull the boat into the bank
and secure to the rings or bollards.

457.56.text:
It's a good idea to take
the mooring ropes back to the boat

460.72.text:
rather than tying
to the ring or bollard itself.

464.52.text:
If there are no rings or bollards,
you'll need to put in mooring pins,

468.52.text:
again, where possible, taking the line
back to the boat to secure.

472.56.text:
Pins should be kept away
from the water's edge,

475.44.text:
but should never be positioned
across the towpath.

478.40.text:
Always tie up
with the ropes going outwards

481.56.text:
at roughly 45 degrees
from the ends of the boat.

484.84.text:
When tying up, you won't need to learn
lots of complex rope-work;

488.72.text:
a few basic hitches
will be all you need.

491.88.text:
The most common
is the round turn and two half hitches,

495.20.text:
used here to secure the back rope
around the boat's bollards.

500.68.text:
If securing to a T-stud,
take a couple of turns around the arms,

504.56.text:
then turn the rope under on itself
to form a locking hitch.

509.80.text:
A good way to secure a rope temporarily
around a bollard is the clove hitch.

515.12.text:
Form a loop in the rope, then take
the free end around the bollard

518.40.text: and place the loop over it.

521.12.text:
These three hitches should cover all
the situations you're likely to meet.

525.48.text: Make sure you never place your fingers

527.36.text:
between the rope
and the bollards or rings.

529.52.text:
If the boat were to move, the rope
could suddenly trap your fingers.

537.36.text:
Locks allow boats
to travel uphill or downhill.

540.32.text:
They provide a chance for the whole crew
to get involved and are often a place

544.08.text:
where you will swap stories and
local knowledge with other boaters.

547.92.text:
Locks do come
in different shapes and sizes,

550.44.text:
but the principle of using them
is pretty much the same.

553.64.text:
A lock is simply a chamber with gates
to contain the water at either end.

558.12.text:
The flow of water in and out of the lock
is controlled by sluices called paddles

562.68.text: which are operated using a windlass.

565.48.text:
The paddles at the top of the lock
are used to let water in

568.80.text:
and those at the bottom,
to let water out,

571.08.text: thus raising or lowering your boat.

576.80.text: Stop the boat well before the lock.

580.92.text:
and put one or more crew members ashore
to get the lock ready.

584.76.text:
If there are only two of you,
you may have a centre line.

587.84.text:
This makes it easier for one person
to hold the boat steady.

591.08.text:
But the centre line should never be used
for mooring up.

595.52.text:
The golden rule at locks is to take
your time and do things methodically.

599.72.text:
Remember that
some of the lock mechanisms

601.88.text: can be stiff and heavy to operate.

603.84.text:
Consider getting your fittest
or strongest crew members

608.80.text:
Make sure you lift any side fenders
before going into a lock.

613.12.text:
It's important that the steerer
stays at the tiller at all times,

616.52.text:
with the engine running
so the boat is always under control.

621.12.text:
Children love to get involved
and help out at locks;

624.20.text: it's all part of the adventure.

626.20.text:
But locks are deep with strong water
flows, so be particularly vigilant

630.36.text:
and make sure
they're always fully supervised.

633.32.text:
For younger children in particular,
the paddle gear is often at head height,

639.40.text:
A spinning or flying windlass
can cause a lot of damage.

642.60.text:
Never leave a windlass unattended
on the paddle mechanism.

648.00.text:
It's important
that crew operating paddles

650.76.text:
stay by their paddle mechanism
until the lock is empty or full,

654.20.text:
and they remain in contact with
the skipper in case of emergency.

658.12.text:
Keep an eye on the boat at all times
and if anything goes wrong,

661.76.text:
close all paddles quickly
and sort out the problem.

666.20.text:
Some locks have anti-vandal devices
which you release with a handcuff key.

673.28.text:
Locks aren't operated
on a first-come, first-served basis,

676.76.text:
but on whether the lock can be used
by another boat without wasting water.

680.68.text:
For example, if you're going downhill
and come to a lock that's empty,

684.96.text:
always check to see if another boat
is approaching from below the lock.

688.68.text:
If so, the lock would be
in their favour.

691.84.text: Wait for them to enter and use the lock.

694.36.text:
You would have had
to fill the lock anyway,

696.48.text:
so you might as well do it
with a boat in it.

699.56.text:
Of course, if there isn't
another boat coming,

701.96.text:
you don't need to wait
for one to arrive.

704.08.text:
It's a case of using a little courtesy
and common sense to save water.

708.88.text: If there isn't another boat coming,

710.68.text:
make sure the gates and paddles
at the far end of the lock are closed

714.08.text:
before lifting the paddles at the end
nearest the boat to fill the lock.

718.04.text:
Make sure the windlass is a snug fit on
the spindle by using the correct hole.

723.00.text:
All paddle mechanisms will have
a safety catch of some type.

726.40.text:
These should always be engaged
where possible.

729.80.text:
When the lock is full, push the gate
open, steer the boat into the lock

733.92.text:
and make sure the top paddles
are fully closed.

736.56.text: Always wind the paddles back down;

739.16.text:
letting them drop can cause them to
break and put the lock out of action.

745.68.text:
Then you can open the paddles in front
to let the water out.

749.80.text:
The steerer needs to keep an eye
on the back of the boat

752.52.text:
to make sure it's always clear
of the top gate cill.

755.48.text:
If necessary, briefly engage
forward gear to keep the boat away.

760.40.text:
Make sure the front is clear
of the bottom gate

762.88.text: and that the boat is floating freely.

766.52.text:
As the lock empties you'll find that
the bottom gates will open quite easily

770.96.text: once the water levels are equalised.

773.24.text:
Trying to force them before they're
ready is a total waste of effort.

777.04.text:
Close all paddles and, unless another
boat is approaching, close the gates.

782.68.text:
Collect your crew,
unless there's another lock close by,

785.84.text:
in which case it's easier
for them to stay off the boat

788.40.text:
and walk ahead
to get the next lock ready.

791.84.text: Going uphill is a similar procedure.

794.20.text:
If the lock is full, make sure
another boat isn't approaching,

797.36.text: then empty it and steer the boat in.

800.00.text:
On most canals,
you won't experience strong currents

803.24.text:
but on some,
water flows round the locks quite fast.

806.76.text:
If you see water movement,
steer into the flow,

809.44.text:
as it will push the front of the boat
away, then back as it passes.

815.28.text:
Close the bottom gates and make sure
the paddles are fully down.

818.92.text:
To fill the lock,
open the top paddles one at a time.

823.80.text:
It's a good idea to initially lift
the first paddle just halfway

827.72.text: to avoid a great in-surge of water

829.88.text:
that can throw the boat
backwards and forwards,

835.12.text:
If the lock is fitted with paddles
in the top gate,

837.88.text:
don't open them
until they're under water.

840.24.text:
Opening them too early can cause
water to swamp the front of the boat.

844.16.text:
Again, open them slowly and keep
a watchful eye on the boat at all times.

849.36.text:
When the lock is full,
the gate will open easily.

852.28.text:
Check that the paddles are all down
and close the gates after the boat,

856.24.text:
unless another boat
is waiting to use the lock.

860.00.text:
Sometimes you'll come across
two or more locks joined together

863.24.text: in what is known as a staircase,

865.12.text:
where the top gate of one lock
is the bottom gate of the next.

869.00.text:
Setting these locks is
slightly different from a normal lock.

873.16.text: Make sure that all paddles are down.

875.28.text:
If you're going uphill,
the bottom lock should be empty

878.12.text: with the upper ones all full.

880.24.text:
You use the water from the upper locks
to fill the lower ones in turn,

886.72.text:
When going downhill, the top lock should
be full with the lower ones empty.

891.12.text:
You empty the upper lock
into the lower ones in turn.

895.00.text:
With staircase locks,
it's important to check

897.32.text:
that another boat hasn't started
in the opposite direction

900.24.text: before you enter the first lock.

902.00.text:
The general rule is
one boat up, one boat down,

905.00.text: unless local notices tell you otherwise.

909.04.text:
Broad locks, that is ones
which are wider than your boat,

914.44.text:
Try to share with another boat
whenever possible to save water.

917.80.text:
And always use the front and back ropes
to steady the boat in the lock.

922.00.text:
When you're using the lock alone
and going uphill,

924.68.text:
always slowly open
the top ground paddle;

927.32.text:
that's the one on the lock side
rather than the one in the gate;

930.40.text: on the same side as the boat first.

932.80.text:
This way,
the flow of water into the lock

935.16.text:
will help to keep the boat against the
lock wall, making it easier to control.

941.08.text: When the lock is part full,

942.72.text:
you can open the paddles
on the opposite side as well.

945.64.text:
Don't use gate paddles
until they're under water.

952.44.text:
You'll find many types of bridges
crossing the waterways.

955.88.text:
Most are fixed,
which you will pass under,

958.24.text:
and others need to be moved
out of the way.

960.64.text:
These are either swing bridges
or lifting bridges

963.60.text:
and will need to be operated
by your crew.

967.12.text:
Remember to check you have
sufficient headroom to pass through.

971.60.text: Stop the boat well before the bridge.

973.96.text:
Leaving yourself plenty of room
will make it easier

976.48.text:
to line the boat up correctly
when you go through the bridge.

982.88.text:
Make sure when you land your crew
that you have the proper key or windlass

986.44.text: to unlock and operate the bridge.

989.32.text:
If the bridge carries traffic,
make sure the road is clear

996.36.text:
and, for a swing bridge,
give it a good, controlled push.

999.44.text: Be ready to slow the swing

1000.96.text:
to prevent the bridge
from bouncing off the buffer stop.

1004.80.text:
Once the boat is through,
close the bridge, secure the lock

1011.28.text:
Lifting bridges will have a winder
which you operate with a windlass,

1015.16.text:
or sometimes a chain or rope
to pull to operate the bridge.

1019.20.text:
When fully open,
unless there's an obvious latch,

1022.08.text:
get an adult to hold on
to keep the bridge raised.

1025.20.text:
Once you're sure that the boat is clear,
gently lower the bridge,

1031.80.text:
Some bridges are powered
and need a facilities key to operate.

1035.84.text:
Make sure you always follow
the instructions

1038.16.text:
and pay particular care
to traffic barriers,

1040.52.text:
unlocking and re-locking them
when leaving.

1042.76.text: And don't forget to retrieve your key.

1053.04.text:
These are quite easy and often fun
to navigate, but they do require care.

1058.04.text:
Tunnels may be narrow,
only allowing one-way traffic,

1061.24.text:
or wide enough for boats
to pass each other.

1063.96.text:
Look for information
and instruction boards

1066.28.text: or traffic lights at the entrance.

1068.56.text:
If you have to wait for another boat
coming through,

1071.08.text:
stay well clear of the tunnel entrance
to give them room to pass.

1075.60.text: Make sure everyone is inside the boat,

1077.76.text:
with nobody's arms or legs
hanging over the side.

1081.68.text:
Prepare the boat by switching on
the headlights and some interior lights.

1085.88.text:
These will help to illuminate
the tunnel walls.

1091.80.text:
Many tunnels are damp, so put some
waterproofs on and have a torch to hand.

1097.88.text:
As you enter the tunnel,
sound one long blast on your horn.

1102.44.text:
Steer by looking at
one side of the tunnel only

1105.32.text: and keep to a moderate speed.

1108.28.text: Some tunnels allow canoes to use them.

1112.96.text:
so have someone as a lookout
in the front of the boat

1115.48.text: to warn the skipper if you see one.

1118.32.text:
Always keep a reasonable distance
between you and any boat in front.

1123.68.text:
If it's two-way traffic,
watch out for oncoming boats

1126.60.text: and pass slowly on the right.

1132.40.text:
If your route includes
a stretch of river,

1134.88.text:
there are some additional factors
to bear in mind.

1137.92.text:
You must follow any specific
instructions which are signposted.

1142.08.text:
Unlike canals,
the water in a river is always moving.

1145.32.text:
In dry weather,
this current is quite gentle,

1147.64.text:
but in prolonged wet weather,
the river has to carry more water,

1151.04.text:
and its speed will increase
and the water level will rise.

1154.68.text: It's easy to tell if the flow is normal.

1156.88.text:
At every river lock,
there are marker boards.

1159.88.text:
At normal river level,
a green band shows.

1163.00.text:
If the level rises, it goes into yellow,
which means take extra care.

1167.68.text:
If the level is in the red,
navigation on the river is prohibited

1171.64.text:
and you should stop and moor safely
until conditions improve.

1176.08.text:
So all you have to do
is check at each lock.

1179.56.text: On some rivers there are flood locks;

1181.92.text:
locks which are open at normal flows,
and closed in strong stream conditions.

1187.08.text:
They're only operated
by Canal & River Trust staff.

1189.96.text: If you come across a closed flood lock,

1192.20.text:
you'll need to wait for
Canal & River Trust staff to open it

1198.48.text: If you need to moor up on a river,

1200.16.text:
always approach the bank
with the boat pointing upstream.

1203.48.text:
If travelling downstream, go beyond
your chosen stopping place,

1207.16.text:
turn around and approach the bank
against the current.

1210.28.text:
This uses the current to slow the boat
down and helps to maintain steering.

1215.40.text:
When tying up, always secure
the upstream rope first.

1219.24.text:
And when setting off,
untie the downstream rope first.

1223.60.text:
Always leave some slack in your ropes
to allow for water level changes.

1227.56.text:
Don't moor overnight
except at designated mooring sites,

1231.44.text: and always use fixed bollards or rings.

1234.92.text:
When approaching bridges, look for signs
showing which arch to go through.

1240.64.text:
Weirs, generally near locks, may have a
sideways current flowing towards them.

1245.28.text:
Be ready for this. Watch for signs
and steer to counteract the current.

1251.12.text:
All boats on rivers must carry an anchor
of adequate size and weight

1254.96.text:
with a suitable length of rope,
secured to a strong point on the boat.

1258.92.text:
The anchor should be stowed
in such a way

1261.00.text:
that it can be deployed
quickly and easily in an emergency.

1264.56.text:
Hire boats which go on rivers
will have a suitable anchor.

1272.24.text:
The rule of the road on the canals is to
steer down the centre of the waterway,

1276.32.text:
but to move to your right
when you meet an oncoming boat.

1281.24.text:
Going faster makes it more likely
that you'll go aground.

1284.32.text:
If you're approaching a bridge
or narrow section, slow down,

1288.40.text:
and if an oncoming boat is closer
to the bridge or narrow section,

1291.68.text:
wave them through and keep to the right
until they're well clear.

1295.40.text:
However, on rivers, the boat
travelling downstream has right of way.

1301.00.text:
The speed limit
on narrow canals is 4mph,

1304.08.text:
which is equivalent to a brisk walking
pace. But this is a maximum speed.

1308.52.text:
On many canals,
particularly if the water is shallow,

1311.44.text: you'll need to go much slower.

1313.28.text:
Going too fast pulls the back of the
boat deeper into the shallow water,

1319.24.text:
The important thing is not to create a
breaking wash which damages the bank.

1324.76.text: If another boat is slower than you,

1326.60.text:
it's usual to keep your distance
and stay behind.

1329.56.text:
If the other boat wants you to overtake,
the skipper will wave you on

1333.00.text:
and pull over to one side
and leave you room to pass slowly.

1337.24.text: A final word here about horn signals.

1340.04.text:
Give a single long blast
when the view ahead is obscured,

1343.48.text:
such as blind bends,
junctions or bridges.

1347.08.text:
On commercial waterways, two
long blasts from an approaching boat

1351.04.text:
means it wishes you to pass
on the wrong side,

1353.64.text: that is, to the left of them.

1359.04.text:
No one should ever end up in the water,
but it could happen,

1362.44.text:
and if it does,
it's best to know what to do.

1365.84.text:
If you're on a canal
or a slow-flowing, shallow river

1368.84.text:
and someone falls overboard,
you should immediately go into neutral.

1372.84.text:
If it's safe to do so,
turn off the engine

1375.36.text:
to prevent the person in the water
being dragged into the propeller.

1378.68.text:
Throw them a lifebelt,
and then ask them if they can stand up.

1381.92.text:
It's more than likely that they'll be
able to wade to the side of most canals.

1386.00.text: Guide the boat slowly to the bank

1388.00.text:
and get one of your crew
to help the person ashore.

1394.32.text:
If you're on a wider river
or deeper waterway,

1396.96.text:
throw a lifebuoy or lifeline
close to them.

1400.20.text:
Manoeuvre the boat to approach them
very carefully from the front

1403.56.text:
in order to keep them well away
from the propeller.

1406.40.text:
If there's any danger of them
getting too close to the propeller,

1412.12.text:
Pull them towards the front and
side of the boat and help them aboard.

1416.72.text:
But the best advice is to take great
care not to fall in in the first place.

1425.20.text: The canals are there for all to enjoy,

1427.64.text:
whether boating, walking,
fishing or cycling,

1430.48.text:
and you need to show consideration
for other users.

1433.92.text:
Your speed is probably
the main thing to bear in mind.

1437.20.text:
When passing moored boats,
slow right down to tick-over speed

1441.12.text:
to avoid your wash pulling craft
away from their moorings

1444.24.text: and possibly pulling out mooring pins.

1447.04.text:
Slow your boat down well in advance
to allow it to lose momentum

1450.80.text: before you reach the moored boats.

1457.20.text:
and keep to the centre of the canal
unless asked to do otherwise.

1461.92.text:
When mooring, always try
to leave room for other boats

1464.76.text:
and never moor on the approach
to a lock or bridge,

1467.96.text:
opposite a winding hole
or at a water point.

1473.64.text:
Some of our bigger waterways
carry freight in big barges.

1477.08.text: They have priority over pleasure boats.

1479.60.text:
Keep well clear
and watch for signals from the skipper,

1482.56.text:
who may need you to move
to give him the deeper water.

1486.08.text:
Barges make a big wash, so when
you moor on commercial waterways,

1492.08.text: Barges also have restricted sight lines.

1495.16.text:
If you can't see the skipper,
he can't see you.

1500.84.text:
It may seem a lot to remember,
but if you take your time,

1504.00.text:
tackle everything slowly
and think things through first,

1507.16.text:
you'll soon get used
to handling your boat confidently.

1510.20.text:
And your time on the waterways
will be enjoyable and safe,

1513.36.text:
for you, for your crew
and for other waterway users.
